title: Why are open chords on stringed instruments also called cowboy chords? - Quora

response.answer_text: Don’t pay these others much mind. They’re trying to sugarcoat the truth…which is that when someone uses the phrase “cowboy chords” for open chords, they mean it derisively. It is/was used by jazz guitarists, who “back in the day”, never used open chord fingerings, and, actually, hardly ever even used major and minor chords that hadn’t been either altered or extended (and they didn’t like fifths much, either). If you were playing cowboy chords, it meant that you couldn’t cut the music. My guitar mentor was a solid jazz player, and tended to call them “baby chords”. He didn’t like to see them. This actually makes sense, for a number of reasons. For one thing, jazz guitarists play a lot of rhythm accompaniment, which needs to be fairly staccato. Those ringy open chords don’t work very well. For another thing, they tend to play in keys like Bb, F, and Eb, and arrangements often include key changes. If you capo up, they smirk. The last reason is the real killer, which is the idea that you should move thru chord changes by half steps whenever possible. Try doing that with baby chords. This is really a very narrow view, though. Blues and various country music styles are built around the open chord sounds, and involve playing single note leads and bass lines against open strings. There’s often a bit of fingerpicking , too That’s featured a lot in today’s music, so if you only play closed position chords, you can’t cut the music. Before I go, here’s an entertaining personal experience. Once, I was working a High School Prom, and for the Prom King and Queen’s dance, the school choir’s Prima Donna (it’s not a put down, it’s what you call the main female singer in a performing group) came out to sing a rather operatic version of “Fire and Rain”, accompanied by a Dixieland-style jazz guitarist. I’ll leave the rest for you to ponder.

Great question! I have haven’t had that request so far but the tradition of the cowboy chords is the stuff of legend. Cowboy chords are mainly triads and they are played by beginners to get started. The cowboy part is the tradition of the western guitar players and singers of the high lonesome territories. Cowboy chords are simple to play and are usually played in the open position. The chords and melodies are simple and the easy pace of the cowboy chords makes for a relaxing and enjoyable experience for both the player and the audience. (The horse, dog, the occasional coyote, and the occasional guest at the campfire.) The heartfelt stories and exciting ballads provided a means of entertainment. The popularity of the cowboy way has exploded through the decades and as we all know, western/cowboy/country is here to stay. C’mon, the cowboy wrote the lyrics "If you won't leave me, I'll find a woman who will!" spoke volumes in that song. Who else could have pulled that one-off? I think it was written by Guitar Junior Brown. If you can find it online, give it a listen. I am a guitarist and no matter what kind of hellfire and brimstone music I create, it doesn’t budge the cowboy way. I have been slow to experience the music that is heartfelt, humorous, and emotional. What got me the most is that many country players look like they could uproot a tree with their bare hands and still sing and play music from the heart in that high lonesome way. 12/4/2019 insert. I have known many country/cowboy guitar players. There are pickers that fly like lightning, others just have a story to tell. The cowboy chords often stand back to let the story speak. It’s the cowboy way! P.S. The tradition of their music transcends many variations but with the unified style of the cowboy way. Cowboys and cowgirls too! The cowgirl performers are a force of their own. I didn’t want to leave them out. Thank you for the great question!
